posts.cooked:
I have a cadre of family and friends that got onto Google Hangouts seven years ago and have never left. They’re sympathetic to moving to something else, and I’d like that something to be Signal (which I use quite a lot and love), but the lack of a way to have automatic backups to something off-phone is an absolute dealbreaker for migrating them.

They’re unwilling to drop a phone, have it die (it’s happened), and lose all of their messages and media in the process (and I don’t blame them). This was one of the reasons that they got off SMS in the first place. The issue isn’t even the backup passwords – storing them in a password manager isn’t bad – but unless they are diligent about manually moving Signal backup files to some off-site/cloud storage location, which they aren’t/won’t be, they will still potentially lose history.

This makes WhatsApp the only real option, and there are plenty of reasons I’d prefer Signal over WhatsApp that I don’t really need to enumerate to this audience.

Is there a reason, other than a principled stand or simple lack of developer capacity, why this can’t be added to the client? I realize it creates the potential for a cloud storage vendor to know that I’m using Signal, but I’m okay with that, so long as what’s then going onto their storage is encrypted via Signal before uploading to it. My family and friends would be too.

iOS: Backup / keeping message history when switching phones

A user uninstalls and re-installs their app and their instinct is that all their data will be preserved. They don’t think “I need to do a backup first.” It doesn’t make sense for us to fight against this instinct, but instead to solve for it. To provide a backup system that matches the level of security Signal strives to provide in all things, but that also doesn’t require the user overhead that is unexpected by the majority. It needs to just work for those who want it.

posts.name: Daniel Seymour
posts.cooked:
If Signal’s goal is to make encrypted communication easy for the world, I shouldn’t be forced to use a third-party app to set up my backups. It’s an extra step and requires a bit of knowledge about how Android works and the file system set up. My father is still upset that Windows changed the file system layout between XP and Vista (basically changing to use separate folders for word docs, photos, and videos). It’s unfamiliar to him and he has no desire to learn something that he feels could change on him at any moment. The same goes with the rest of my family. They will have no desire to learn how to use Signal backups properly. They aren’t concerned enough about privacy to learn. They would be much more inclined to do it though if they had a feature set that could act as a drop-in SMS replacement plus fancier features when communicating with Signal users.

Since I would be the one pushing them to use Signal, I have to care about breaking them. I can’t move them from an app they are using if it will remove a functionality they are using or will use. That’s been the ethos of the Linux kernel team for a very long time and it has worked for them.

Currently, these family members don’t have to worry about taking their phone into a store and swapping it because their messages get moved across devices, either via the Android phone-to-phone data transfer or because it’s all stored in a service ala FB Messenger. If I suddenly tell them that they will lose that functionality, I’m going to be on the hook for every time they lose messages because something happened to their phone or they bought a new one.

To borrow the kernel team’s slogan: I can’t break [the] user[space].

According to one of the developers it’s being worked on

iOS: Backup / keeping message history when switching phones

The future for moving your data between devices in Signal likely looks like a choice between direct peer-to-peer transfer or restoration from some form of secure network storage.

iOS: Backup / keeping message history when switching phones

All that to say, we’re working on it. We’re developing and exploring new technologies like Secure Value Recovery and Private Group Systems that we hope will help us set up the cryptographic frameworks for doing things like this in the future. It’s possible we’ll provide some interim Android style solution now that #3 exists, but it’s a lot of time to invest into something that is likely not the right solution in the end.
